segment.source: Deploy Windows To Go in your organization (Windows 10)
segment.target: Deploy Windows To Go in your organization (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic helps you to deploy Windows To Go in your organization.
segment.target: This topic helps you to deploy Windows To Go in your organization.

segment.source: Deploy Windows To Go in your organization
segment.target: Deploy Windows To Go in your organization

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic helps you to deploy Windows To Go in your organization.
segment.target: This topic helps you to deploy Windows To Go in your organization.

segment.source: Before you begin deployment, make sure that you have reviewed the topics Windows To Go: feature overview and Prepare your organization for Windows To Go to ensure that you have the correct hardware and are prepared to complete the deployment.
segment.target: Before you begin deployment, make sure that you have reviewed the topics Windows To Go: feature overview and Prepare your organization for Windows To Go to ensure that you have the correct hardware and are prepared to complete the deployment.

segment.source: You can then use the steps in this topic to start your Windows To Go deployment.
segment.target: You can then use the steps in this topic to start your Windows To Go deployment.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This topic includes sample Windows PowerShell cmdlets that you can use to automate some of the procedures described.
segment.target: This topic includes sample Windows PowerShell cmdlets that you can use to automate some of the procedures described.

segment.source: For more information, see Using Cmdlets.
segment.target: For more information, see Using Cmdlets.

segment.source: Deployment tips
segment.target: Deployment tips

segment.source: The following is a list of items that you should be aware of before you start the deployment process:
segment.target: The following is a list of items that you should be aware of before you start the deployment process:

segment.source: Only use recommended USB drives for Windows To Go.
segment.target: Only use recommended USB drives for Windows To Go.

segment.source: Use of other drives is not supported.
segment.target: Use of other drives is not supported.

segment.source: Check the list at Windows To Go: feature overview for the latest USB drives certified for use as Windows To Go drives.
segment.target: Check the list at Windows To Go: feature overview for the latest USB drives certified for use as Windows To Go drives.

segment.source: After you provision a new workspace, always eject a Windows To Go drive using the Safely Remove Hardware and Eject Media control that can be found in the notification area or in Windows Explorer.
segment.target: After you provision a new workspace, always eject a Windows To Go drive using the Safely Remove Hardware and Eject Media control that can be found in the notification area or in Windows Explorer.

segment.source: Removing the drive from the USB port without ejecting it first can cause the drive to become corrupted.
segment.target: Removing the drive from the USB port without ejecting it first can cause the drive to become corrupted.

segment.source: When running a Windows To Go workspace, always shutdown the workspace before unplugging the drive.
segment.target: When running a Windows To Go workspace, always shutdown the workspace before unplugging the drive.

segment.source: System Center 2012 Configuration Manager SP1 and later includes support for user self-provisioning of Windows To Go drives.
segment.target: System Center 2012 Configuration Manager SP1 and later includes support for user self-provisioning of Windows To Go drives.

segment.source: You can download Configuration Manager for evaluation from the Microsoft TechNet Evaluation Center.
segment.target: You can download Configuration Manager for evaluation from the Microsoft TechNet Evaluation Center.

segment.source: For more information on this deployment option, see How to Provision Windows To Go in Configuration Manager.
segment.target: For more information on this deployment option, see How to Provision Windows To Go in Configuration Manager.

segment.source: If you are planning on using a USB drive duplicator to duplicate Windows To Go drives, do not configure offline domain join or BitLocker on the drive.
segment.target: If you are planning on using a USB drive duplicator to duplicate Windows To Go drives, do not configure offline domain join or BitLocker on the drive.

segment.source: Basic deployment steps
segment.target: Basic deployment steps

segment.source: Unless you are using a customized operating system image, your initial Windows To Go workspace will not be domain joined and will not contain applications.
segment.target: Unless you are using a customized operating system image, your initial Windows To Go workspace will not be domain joined and will not contain applications.

segment.source: This is exactly like a new installation of Windows on a desktop or laptop computer.
segment.target: This is exactly like a new installation of Windows on a desktop or laptop computer.

segment.source: When planning your deployment, you should develop methods to join Windows to Go drives to the domain and install the standard applications that users in your organization require.
segment.target: When planning your deployment, you should develop methods to join Windows to Go drives to the domain and install the standard applications that users in your organization require.

segment.source: These methods probably will be similar to the ones used for setting up desktop and laptop computers with domain privileges and applications.
segment.target: These methods probably will be similar to the ones used for setting up desktop and laptop computers with domain privileges and applications.

segment.source: This section describes the instructions for creating the correct disk layout on the USB drive, applying the operating system image and the core Windows To Go specific configurations to the drive.
segment.target: This section describes the instructions for creating the correct disk layout on the USB drive, applying the operating system image and the core Windows To Go specific configurations to the drive.

segment.source: The following steps are used in both small-scale and large-scale Windows To Go deployment scenarios.
segment.target: The following steps are used in both small-scale and large-scale Windows To Go deployment scenarios.

segment.source: Completing these steps will give you a generic Windows To Go drive that can be distributed to your users and then customized for their usage as needed.
segment.target: Completing these steps will give you a generic Windows To Go drive that can be distributed to your users and then customized for their usage as needed.

segment.source: This drive is also appropriate for use with USB drive duplicators.
segment.target: This drive is also appropriate for use with USB drive duplicators.

segment.source: Your specific deployment scenarios will involve more than just these basic steps but these additional deployment considerations are similar to traditional PC deployment and can be incorporated into your Windows To Go deployment plan.
segment.target: Your specific deployment scenarios will involve more than just these basic steps but these additional deployment considerations are similar to traditional PC deployment and can be incorporated into your Windows To Go deployment plan.

segment.source: For additional information, see Windows Deployment Options.
segment.target: For additional information, see Windows Deployment Options.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: If you are planning to use the generic Windows To Go drive as the master drive in a USB duplicator, the drive should not be booted.
segment.target: If you are planning to use the generic Windows To Go drive as the master drive in a USB duplicator, the drive should not be booted.

segment.source: If the drive has been booted inadvertently it should be reprovisioned prior to duplication.
segment.target: If the drive has been booted inadvertently it should be reprovisioned prior to duplication.

segment.source: Create the Windows To Go workspace
segment.target: Create the Windows To Go workspace

segment.source: In this step we are creating the operating system image that will be used on the Windows To Go drives.
segment.target: In this step we are creating the operating system image that will be used on the Windows To Go drives.

segment.source: You can use the Windows To Go Creator Wizard or you can do this manually using a combination of Windows PowerShell and command-line tools.
segment.target: You can use the Windows To Go Creator Wizard or you can do this manually using a combination of Windows PowerShell and command-line tools.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: The preferred method for creating a single Windows To Go drive is to use the Windows To Go Creator Wizard included in Windows 10 Enterprise and Windows 10 Education.
segment.target: The preferred method for creating a single Windows To Go drive is to use the Windows To Go Creator Wizard included in Windows 10 Enterprise and Windows 10 Education.

segment.source: To create a Windows To Go workspace with the Windows To Go Creator Wizard
segment.target: To create a Windows To Go workspace with the Windows To Go Creator Wizard

segment.source: Sign into your Windows PC using an account with Administrator privileges.
segment.target: Sign into your Windows PC using an account with Administrator privileges.

segment.source: Insert the USB drive that you want to use as your Windows To Go drive into your PC.
segment.target: Insert the USB drive that you want to use as your Windows To Go drive into your PC.

segment.source: Verify that the .wim file location (which can be a network share, a DVD , or a USB drive) is accessible and that it contains a valid Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education image that has been generalized using sysprep.
segment.target: Verify that the .wim file location (which can be a network share, a DVD , or a USB drive) is accessible and that it contains a valid Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education image that has been generalized using sysprep.

segment.source: Many environments can use the same image for both Windows To Go and desktop deployments.
segment.target: Many environments can use the same image for both Windows To Go and desktop deployments.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For more information about .wim files, see Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information about .wim files, see Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM) Technical Reference.

segment.source: For more information about using sysprep, see Sysprep Overview.
segment.target: For more information about using sysprep, see Sysprep Overview.

segment.source: Using Cortana, search for Windows To Go and then press Enter.
segment.target: Using Cortana, search for Windows To Go and then press Enter.

segment.source: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.
segment.target: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.

segment.source: The Windows To Go Creator Wizard opens.
segment.target: The Windows To Go Creator Wizard opens.

segment.source: On the Choose the drive you want to use page select the drive that represents the USB drive you inserted previously, then click Next.
segment.target: On the Choose the drive you want to use page select the drive that represents the USB drive you inserted previously, then click Next.

segment.source: On the Choose a Windows image page, click Add Search Location and then navigate to the .wim file location and click select folder.
segment.target: On the Choose a Windows image page, click Add Search Location and then navigate to the .wim file location and click select folder.

segment.source: The wizard will display the installable images present in the folder; select the Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education image you wish to use and then click Next.
segment.target: The wizard will display the installable images present in the folder; select the Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Education image you wish to use and then click Next.

segment.source: (Optional) On the Set a BitLocker password (optional) page, you can select Use BitLocker with my Windows To Go Workspace to encrypt your Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: (Optional) On the Set a BitLocker password (optional) page, you can select Use BitLocker with my Windows To Go Workspace to encrypt your Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: If you do not wish to encrypt the drive at this time, click Skip.
segment.target: If you do not wish to encrypt the drive at this time, click Skip.

segment.source: If you decide you want to add BitLocker protection later, see Enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive for instructions.
segment.target: If you decide you want to add BitLocker protection later, see Enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive for instructions.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: If you are planning to use a USB-Duplicator to create multiple Windows To Go drives, do not enable BitLocker.
segment.target: If you are planning to use a USB-Duplicator to create multiple Windows To Go drives, do not enable BitLocker.

segment.source: Drives protected with BitLocker should not be duplicated.
segment.target: Drives protected with BitLocker should not be duplicated.

segment.source: If you choose to encrypt the Windows To Go drive now:
segment.target: If you choose to encrypt the Windows To Go drive now:

segment.source: Type a password that is at least eight characters long and conforms to your organizations password complexity policy.
segment.target: Type a password that is at least eight characters long and conforms to your organizations password complexity policy.

segment.source: This password will be provided before the operating system is started so any characters you use must be able to be interpreted by the firmware.
segment.target: This password will be provided before the operating system is started so any characters you use must be able to be interpreted by the firmware.

segment.source: Some firmware does not support non-ASCII characters.
segment.target: Some firmware does not support non-ASCII characters.

segment.source: Retype the password, and then click Next.
segment.target: Retype the password, and then click Next.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The BitLocker recovery password will be saved in the documents library of the computer used to create the workspace automatically.
segment.target: The BitLocker recovery password will be saved in the documents library of the computer used to create the workspace automatically.

segment.source: If your organization is using Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) to store recovery passwords it will also be saved in AD DS under the computer account of the computer used to create the workspace.
segment.target: If your organization is using Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) to store recovery passwords it will also be saved in AD DS under the computer account of the computer used to create the workspace.

segment.source: This password will be used only if you need to recover access to the drive because the BitLocker password specified in the previous step is not available, such as if a password is lost or forgotten.
segment.target: This password will be used only if you need to recover access to the drive because the BitLocker password specified in the previous step is not available, such as if a password is lost or forgotten.

segment.source: For more information about BitLocker and AD DS, see Active Directory Domain Services considerations.
segment.target: For more information about BitLocker and AD DS, see Active Directory Domain Services considerations.

segment.source: Verify that the USB drive inserted is the one you want to provision for Windows To Go and then click Create to start the Windows To Go workspace creation process.
segment.target: Verify that the USB drive inserted is the one you want to provision for Windows To Go and then click Create to start the Windows To Go workspace creation process.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: The USB drive identified will be reformatted as part of the Windows To Go provisioning process and any data on the drive will be erased.
segment.target: The USB drive identified will be reformatted as part of the Windows To Go provisioning process and any data on the drive will be erased.

segment.source: Wait for the creation process to complete, which can take 20 to 30 minutes.
segment.target: Wait for the creation process to complete, which can take 20 to 30 minutes.

segment.source: A completion page will be displayed that tells you when your Windows To Go workspace is ready to use.
segment.target: A completion page will be displayed that tells you when your Windows To Go workspace is ready to use.

segment.source: From the completion page you can configure the Windows To Go startup options to configure the current computer as a Windows To Go host computer.
segment.target: From the completion page you can configure the Windows To Go startup options to configure the current computer as a Windows To Go host computer.

segment.source: Your Windows To Go workspace is now ready to be started.
segment.target: Your Windows To Go workspace is now ready to be started.

segment.source: You can now prepare a host computer using the Windows To Go startup options and boot your Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: You can now prepare a host computer using the Windows To Go startup options and boot your Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: Windows PowerShell equivalent commands
segment.target: Windows PowerShell equivalent commands

segment.source: The following Windows PowerShell cmdlet or cmdlets perform the same function as the preceding procedure.
segment.target: The following Windows PowerShell cmdlet or cmdlets perform the same function as the preceding procedure.

segment.source: Enter each cmdlet on a single line, even though they may appear word-wrapped across several lines here because of formatting constraints.
segment.target: Enter each cmdlet on a single line, even though they may appear word-wrapped across several lines here because of formatting constraints.

segment.source: This procedure can only be used on PCs that are running Windows 10.
segment.target: This procedure can only be used on PCs that are running Windows 10.

segment.source: Before starting, ensure that only the USB drive that you want to provision as a Windows To Go drive is connected to the PC.
segment.target: Before starting, ensure that only the USB drive that you want to provision as a Windows To Go drive is connected to the PC.

segment.source: Using Cortana, search for powershell, right-click Windows PowerShell, and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Using Cortana, search for powershell, right-click Windows PowerShell, and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: In the Windows PowerShell session type the following commands to partition a master boot record (MBR) disk for use with a FAT32 system partition and an NTFS-formatted operating system partition.
segment.target: In the Windows PowerShell session type the following commands to partition a master boot record (MBR) disk for use with a FAT32 system partition and an NTFS-formatted operating system partition.

segment.source: This disk layout can support computers that use either UEFI or BIOS firmware:
segment.target: This disk layout can support computers that use either UEFI or BIOS firmware:

segment.source: Next you need to apply the operating system image that you want to use with Windows To Go to the operating system partition you just created on the disk (this may take 30 minutes or longer, depending on the size of the image and the speed of your USB connection).
segment.target: Next you need to apply the operating system image that you want to use with Windows To Go to the operating system partition you just created on the disk (this may take 30 minutes or longer, depending on the size of the image and the speed of your USB connection).

segment.source: The following command shows how this can be accomplished using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management command-line tool (DISM):
segment.target: The following command shows how this can be accomplished using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management command-line tool (DISM):

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: The index number must be set correctly to a valid Enterprise image in the .WIM file.
segment.target: The index number must be set correctly to a valid Enterprise image in the .WIM file.

segment.source: Now use the bcdboot command line tool to move the necessary boot components to the system partition on the disk.
segment.target: Now use the bcdboot command line tool to move the necessary boot components to the system partition on the disk.

segment.source: This helps ensure that the boot components, operating system versions, and architectures match.
segment.target: This helps ensure that the boot components, operating system versions, and architectures match.

segment.source: The parameter indicates that boot components for UEFI and BIOS should be placed on the system partition of the disk.
segment.target: The parameter indicates that boot components for UEFI and BIOS should be placed on the system partition of the disk.

segment.source: The following example illustrates this step:
segment.target: The following example illustrates this step:

segment.source: Apply SAN policy—OFFLINEINTERNAL - “4” to prevent the operating system from automatically bringing online any internally connected disk.
segment.target: Apply SAN policy—OFFLINEINTERNAL - “4” to prevent the operating system from automatically bringing online any internally connected disk.

segment.source: This is done by creating and saving a sanpolicy.xml file on the disk.
segment.target: This is done by creating and saving a sanpolicy.xml file on the disk.

segment.source: The following example illustrates this step:
segment.target: The following example illustrates this step:

segment.source: Place the sanpolicy.xml file created in the previous step into the root directory of the Windows partition on the Windows To Go drive (W: from the previous examples) and run the following command:
segment.target: Place the sanpolicy.xml file created in the previous step into the root directory of the Windows partition on the Windows To Go drive (W: from the previous examples) and run the following command:

segment.source: Create an answer file (unattend.xml) that disables the use of Windows Recovery Environment with Windows To Go.
segment.target: Create an answer file (unattend.xml) that disables the use of Windows Recovery Environment with Windows To Go.

segment.source: You can use the following code sample to create a new answer file or you can paste it into an existing answer file:
segment.target: You can use the following code sample to create a new answer file or you can paste it into an existing answer file:

segment.source: Once the answer file has been saved, copy unattend.xml into the sysprep folder on the Windows To Go drive (for example, W:WindowsSystem32sysprep
segment.target: Once the answer file has been saved, copy unattend.xml into the sysprep folder on the Windows To Go drive (for example, W:WindowsSystem32sysprep

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Setup unattend files are processed based on their location.
segment.target: Setup unattend files are processed based on their location.

segment.source: Setup will place a temporary unattend file into the %systemroot%panther folder which is the first location that setup will check for installation information.
segment.target: Setup will place a temporary unattend file into the %systemroot%panther folder which is the first location that setup will check for installation information.

segment.source: You should make sure that folder does not contain a previous version of an unattend.xml file to ensure that the one you just created is used.
segment.target: You should make sure that folder does not contain a previous version of an unattend.xml file to ensure that the one you just created is used.

segment.source: If you do not wish to boot your Windows To Go device on this computer and want to remove it to boot it on another PC, be sure to use the Safely Remove Hardware and Eject Media option to safely disconnect the drive before physically removing it from the PC.
segment.target: If you do not wish to boot your Windows To Go device on this computer and want to remove it to boot it on another PC, be sure to use the Safely Remove Hardware and Eject Media option to safely disconnect the drive before physically removing it from the PC.

segment.source: Your Windows To Go workspace is now ready to be started.
segment.target: Your Windows To Go workspace is now ready to be started.

segment.source: You can now prepare a host computer using the Windows To Go startup options to test your workspace configuration, configure the workspace for offline domain join, or enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: You can now prepare a host computer using the Windows To Go startup options to test your workspace configuration, configure the workspace for offline domain join, or enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: To prepare a host computer
segment.target: To prepare a host computer

segment.source: Computers running Windows 8 and later can be configured as host computers that use Windows To Go automatically whenever a Windows To Go workspace is available at startup.
segment.target: Computers running Windows 8 and later can be configured as host computers that use Windows To Go automatically whenever a Windows To Go workspace is available at startup.

segment.source: When the Windows To Go startup options are enabled on a host computer, Windows will divert startup to the Windows To Go drive whenever it is attached to the computer.
segment.target: When the Windows To Go startup options are enabled on a host computer, Windows will divert startup to the Windows To Go drive whenever it is attached to the computer.

segment.source: This makes it easy to switch from using the host computer to using the Windows To Go workspace.
segment.target: This makes it easy to switch from using the host computer to using the Windows To Go workspace.

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: If you will be using a PC running Windows 7 as your host computer, see Tips for configuring your BIOS settings to work with Windows To Go for information to help you prepare the host computer.
segment.target: If you will be using a PC running Windows 7 as your host computer, see Tips for configuring your BIOS settings to work with Windows To Go for information to help you prepare the host computer.

segment.source: If you want to use the Windows To Go workspace, simply shut down the computer, plug in the Windows To Go drive, and turn on the computer.
segment.target: If you want to use the Windows To Go workspace, simply shut down the computer, plug in the Windows To Go drive, and turn on the computer.

segment.source: To use the host computer, shut down the Windows To Go workspace, unplug the Windows To Go drive, and turn on the computer.
segment.target: To use the host computer, shut down the Windows To Go workspace, unplug the Windows To Go drive, and turn on the computer.

segment.source: To set the Windows To Go Startup options for host computers running Windows 10:
segment.target: To set the Windows To Go Startup options for host computers running Windows 10:

segment.source: Using Cortana, search for Windows To Go startup options and then press Enter.
segment.target: Using Cortana, search for Windows To Go startup options and then press Enter.

segment.source: In the Windows To Go Startup Options dialog box, select Yes, and then click Save Changes to configure the computer to boot from USB
segment.target: In the Windows To Go Startup Options dialog box, select Yes, and then click Save Changes to configure the computer to boot from USB

segment.source: For host computers running Windows 8 or Windows 8.1:
segment.target: For host computers running Windows 8 or Windows 8.1:

segment.source: Press Windows logo key+W, search for Windows To Go startup options, and then press Enter.
segment.target: Press Windows logo key+W, search for Windows To Go startup options, and then press Enter.

segment.source: In the Windows To Go Startup Options dialog box, select Yes, and then click Save Changes to configure the computer to boot from USB.
segment.target: In the Windows To Go Startup Options dialog box, select Yes, and then click Save Changes to configure the computer to boot from USB.

segment.source: You can configure your organization's computers to automatically start from the USB drive by enabling the following Group Policy setting:
segment.target: You can configure your organization's computers to automatically start from the USB drive by enabling the following Group Policy setting:

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsPortable Operating SystemWindows To Go Default Startup Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsPortable Operating SystemWindows To Go Default Startup Options

segment.source: After this policy setting is enabled, automatic starting of a Windows To Go workspace will be attempted when a USB drive is connected to the computer when it is started.
segment.target: After this policy setting is enabled, automatic starting of a Windows To Go workspace will be attempted when a USB drive is connected to the computer when it is started.

segment.source: Users will not be able to use the Windows To Go Startup Options to change this behavior.
segment.target: Users will not be able to use the Windows To Go Startup Options to change this behavior.

segment.source: If you disable this policy setting, booting to Windows To Go when a USB drive is connected will not occur unless a user configures the option manually in the firmware.
segment.target: If you disable this policy setting, booting to Windows To Go when a USB drive is connected will not occur unless a user configures the option manually in the firmware.

segment.source: If you do not configure this policy setting, users who are members of the Administrators group can enable or disable booting from a USB drive using the Windows To Go Startup Options.
segment.target: If you do not configure this policy setting, users who are members of the Administrators group can enable or disable booting from a USB drive using the Windows To Go Startup Options.

segment.source: Your host computer is now ready to boot directly into Windows To Go workspace when it is inserted prior to starting the computer.
segment.target: Your host computer is now ready to boot directly into Windows To Go workspace when it is inserted prior to starting the computer.

segment.source: Optionally you can perform Configure Windows To Go workspace for offline domain join and Enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: Optionally you can perform Configure Windows To Go workspace for offline domain join and Enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: Booting your Windows To Go workspace
segment.target: Booting your Windows To Go workspace

segment.source: After you have configured your host PC to boot from USB, you can use the following procedure to boot your Windows To Go workspace:
segment.target: After you have configured your host PC to boot from USB, you can use the following procedure to boot your Windows To Go workspace:

segment.source: To boot your workspace
segment.target: To boot your workspace

segment.source: Make sure that the host PC is not in a sleep state.
segment.target: Make sure that the host PC is not in a sleep state.

segment.source: If the computer is in a sleep state, either shut it down or hibernate it.
segment.target: If the computer is in a sleep state, either shut it down or hibernate it.

segment.source: Insert the Windows To Go USB drive directly into a USB 3.0 or USB 2.0 port on the PC.
segment.target: Insert the Windows To Go USB drive directly into a USB 3.0 or USB 2.0 port on the PC.

segment.source: Do not use a USB hub or extender.
segment.target: Do not use a USB hub or extender.

segment.source: Turn on the PC.
segment.target: Turn on the PC.

segment.source: If your Windows To Go drive is protected with BitLocker you will be asked to type the password, otherwise the workspace will boot directly into the Windows To Go workspace.
segment.target: If your Windows To Go drive is protected with BitLocker you will be asked to type the password, otherwise the workspace will boot directly into the Windows To Go workspace.

segment.source: Advanced deployment steps
segment.target: Advanced deployment steps

segment.source: The following steps are used for more advanced deployments where you want to have further control over the configuration of the Windows To Go drives, ensure that they are correctly configured for remote access to your organizational resources, and have been protected with BitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: The following steps are used for more advanced deployments where you want to have further control over the configuration of the Windows To Go drives, ensure that they are correctly configured for remote access to your organizational resources, and have been protected with BitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: Configure Windows To Go workspace for remote access
segment.target: Configure Windows To Go workspace for remote access

segment.source: Making sure that Windows To Go workspaces are effective when used off premises is essential to a successful deployment.
segment.target: Making sure that Windows To Go workspaces are effective when used off premises is essential to a successful deployment.

segment.source: One of the key benefits of Windows To Go is the ability for your users to use the enterprise managed domain joined workspace on an unmanaged computer which is outside your corporate network.
segment.target: One of the key benefits of Windows To Go is the ability for your users to use the enterprise managed domain joined workspace on an unmanaged computer which is outside your corporate network.

segment.source: To enable this usage, typically you would provision the USB drive as described in the basic deployment instructions and then add the configuration to support domain joining of the workspace, installation of any line-of-business applications, and configuration of your chosen remote connectivity solution such as a virtual private network client or DirectAccess.
segment.target: To enable this usage, typically you would provision the USB drive as described in the basic deployment instructions and then add the configuration to support domain joining of the workspace, installation of any line-of-business applications, and configuration of your chosen remote connectivity solution such as a virtual private network client or DirectAccess.

segment.source: Once these configurations have been performed the user can work from the workspace using a computer that is off-premises.
segment.target: Once these configurations have been performed the user can work from the workspace using a computer that is off-premises.

segment.source: The following procedure allows you to provision domain joined Windows To Go workspaces for workers that do not have physical access to your corporate network.
segment.target: The following procedure allows you to provision domain joined Windows To Go workspaces for workers that do not have physical access to your corporate network.

segment.source: Prerequisites for remote access scenario
segment.target: Prerequisites for remote access scenario

segment.source: A domain-joined computer running Windows 8 or later and is configured as a Windows To Go host computer
segment.target: A domain-joined computer running Windows 8 or later and is configured as a Windows To Go host computer

segment.source: A Windows To Go drive that hasn’t been booted or joined to the domain using unattend settings.
segment.target: A Windows To Go drive that hasn’t been booted or joined to the domain using unattend settings.

segment.source: A domain user account with rights to add computer accounts to the domain and is a member of the Administrator group on the Windows To Go host computer
segment.target: A domain user account with rights to add computer accounts to the domain and is a member of the Administrator group on the Windows To Go host computer

segment.source: DirectAccess configured on the domain
segment.target: DirectAccess configured on the domain

segment.source: To configure your Windows To Go workspace for remote access
segment.target: To configure your Windows To Go workspace for remote access

segment.source: Start the host computer and sign in using a user account with privileges to add workstations to the domain and then run the following command from an elevated command prompt replacing the example placeholder parameters (denoted by ) with the ones applicable for your environment:
segment.target: Start the host computer and sign in using a user account with privileges to add workstations to the domain and then run the following command from an elevated command prompt replacing the example placeholder parameters (denoted by ) with the ones applicable for your environment:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The /certtemplate parameter supports the use of certificate templates for distributing certificates for DirectAccess, if your organization is not using certificate templates you can omit this parameter.
segment.target: The /certtemplate parameter supports the use of certificate templates for distributing certificates for DirectAccess, if your organization is not using certificate templates you can omit this parameter.

segment.source: Additionally, if are using djoin.exe with Windows Server 2008-based Domain Controllers, append the /downlevel switch during provisioning.
segment.target: Additionally, if are using djoin.exe with Windows Server 2008-based Domain Controllers, append the /downlevel switch during provisioning.

segment.source: For more information see the Offline Domain Join Step-by-Step guide.
segment.target: For more information see the Offline Domain Join Step-by-Step guide.

segment.source: Insert the Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: Insert the Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: Launch an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt by right-clicking the Windows PowerShell shortcut in the taskbar, and then clicking Run as Administrator.
segment.target: Launch an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt by right-clicking the Windows PowerShell shortcut in the taskbar, and then clicking Run as Administrator.

segment.source: From the Windows PowerShell command prompt run:
segment.target: From the Windows PowerShell command prompt run:

segment.source: Next you need to apply the operating system image that you want to use with Windows To Go to the operating system partition you just created on the disk (this may take 30 minutes or longer, depending on the size of the image and the speed of your USB connection).
segment.target: Next you need to apply the operating system image that you want to use with Windows To Go to the operating system partition you just created on the disk (this may take 30 minutes or longer, depending on the size of the image and the speed of your USB connection).

segment.source: The following command shows how this can be accomplished using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management command-line tool (DISM):
segment.target: The following command shows how this can be accomplished using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management command-line tool (DISM):

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: The index number must be set correctly to a valid Enterprise image in the .WIM file.
segment.target: The index number must be set correctly to a valid Enterprise image in the .WIM file.

segment.source: Once those commands have completed, run the following command:
segment.target: Once those commands have completed, run the following command:

segment.source: Next, we will need to edit the unattend.xml file to configure the first run (OOBE) settings.
segment.target: Next, we will need to edit the unattend.xml file to configure the first run (OOBE) settings.

segment.source: In this example we are hiding the Microsoft Software License Terms (EULA) page, configuring automatic updates to install important and recommended updates automatically, and identifying this workspace as part of a private office network.
segment.target: In this example we are hiding the Microsoft Software License Terms (EULA) page, configuring automatic updates to install important and recommended updates automatically, and identifying this workspace as part of a private office network.

segment.source: You can use other OOBE settings that you have configured for your organization if desired.
segment.target: You can use other OOBE settings that you have configured for your organization if desired.

segment.source: For more information about the OOBE settings, see OOBE:
segment.target: For more information about the OOBE settings, see OOBE:

segment.source: Safely remove the Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: Safely remove the Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: From a host computer, either on or off premises, start the computer and boot the Windows To Go workspace.
segment.target: From a host computer, either on or off premises, start the computer and boot the Windows To Go workspace.

segment.source: If on premises using a host computer with a direct network connection, sign on using your domain credentials.
segment.target: If on premises using a host computer with a direct network connection, sign on using your domain credentials.

segment.source: If off premises, join a wired or wireless network with internet access and then sign on again using your domain credentials.
segment.target: If off premises, join a wired or wireless network with internet access and then sign on again using your domain credentials.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Depending on your DirectAccess configuration you might be asked to insert your smart card to logon to the domain.
segment.target: Depending on your DirectAccess configuration you might be asked to insert your smart card to logon to the domain.

segment.source: You should now be able to access your organization’s network resources and work from your Windows To Go workspace as you would normally work from your standard desktop computer on premises.
segment.target: You should now be able to access your organization’s network resources and work from your Windows To Go workspace as you would normally work from your standard desktop computer on premises.

segment.source: Enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive
segment.target: Enable BitLocker protection for your Windows To Go drive

segment.source: Enabling BitLocker on your Windows To Go drive will help ensure that your data is protected from unauthorized use and that if your Windows To Go drive is lost or stolen it will not be easy for an unauthorized person to obtain confidential data or use the workspace to gain access to protected resources in your organization.
segment.target: Enabling BitLocker on your Windows To Go drive will help ensure that your data is protected from unauthorized use and that if your Windows To Go drive is lost or stolen it will not be easy for an unauthorized person to obtain confidential data or use the workspace to gain access to protected resources in your organization.

segment.source: When BitLocker is enabled, each time you boot your Windows To Go drive, you will be asked to provide the BitLocker password to unlock the drive.
segment.target: When BitLocker is enabled, each time you boot your Windows To Go drive, you will be asked to provide the BitLocker password to unlock the drive.

segment.source: The following procedure provides the steps for enabling BitLocker on your Windows To Go drive:
segment.target: The following procedure provides the steps for enabling BitLocker on your Windows To Go drive:

segment.source: Prerequisites for enabling BitLocker scenario
segment.target: Prerequisites for enabling BitLocker scenario

segment.source: A Windows To Go drive that can be successfully provisioned.
segment.target: A Windows To Go drive that can be successfully provisioned.

segment.source: A computer running Windows 8 configured as a Windows To Go host computer
segment.target: A computer running Windows 8 configured as a Windows To Go host computer

segment.source: Review the following Group Policy settings for BitLocker Drive Encryption and modify the configuration as necessary:
segment.target: Review the following Group Policy settings for BitLocker Drive Encryption and modify the configuration as necessary:

segment.source: Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesRequire additional authentication at startup.
segment.target: Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesRequire additional authentication at startup.

segment.source: This policy allows the use of a password key protector with an operating system drive; this policy must be enabled to configure BitLocker from within the Windows To Go workspace.
segment.target: This policy allows the use of a password key protector with an operating system drive; this policy must be enabled to configure BitLocker from within the Windows To Go workspace.

segment.source: This policy setting allows you to configure whether BitLocker requires additional authentication each time the computer starts and whether you are using BitLocker with or without a Trusted Platform Module (TPM).
segment.target: This policy setting allows you to configure whether BitLocker requires additional authentication each time the computer starts and whether you are using BitLocker with or without a Trusted Platform Module (TPM).

segment.source: You must enable this setting and select the Allow BitLocker without a compatible TPM check box and then enable the Configure use of passwords for operating system drives setting.
segment.target: You must enable this setting and select the Allow BitLocker without a compatible TPM check box and then enable the Configure use of passwords for operating system drives setting.

segment.source: Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesConfigure use of passwords for operating system drives.
segment.target: Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesConfigure use of passwords for operating system drives.

segment.source: This policy setting enables passwords to be used to unlock BitLocker-protected operating system drives and provides the means to configure complexity and length requirements on passwords for Windows To Go workspaces.
segment.target: This policy setting enables passwords to be used to unlock BitLocker-protected operating system drives and provides the means to configure complexity and length requirements on passwords for Windows To Go workspaces.

segment.source: For the complexity requirement setting to be effective the Group Policy setting Password must meet complexity requirements located in Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsAccount PoliciesPassword Policy must be also enabled.
segment.target: For the complexity requirement setting to be effective the Group Policy setting Password must meet complexity requirements located in Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsAccount PoliciesPassword Policy must be also enabled.

segment.source: Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesEnable use of BitLocker authentication requiring preboot keyboard input on slates.
segment.target: Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesEnable use of BitLocker authentication requiring preboot keyboard input on slates.

segment.source: This policy setting allows users to enable authentication options that require user input from the preboot environment even if the platform indicates a lack of preboot input capability.
segment.target: This policy setting allows users to enable authentication options that require user input from the preboot environment even if the platform indicates a lack of preboot input capability.

segment.source: If this setting is not enabled, passwords cannot be used to unlock BitLocker-protected operating system drives.
segment.target: If this setting is not enabled, passwords cannot be used to unlock BitLocker-protected operating system drives.

segment.source: You can choose to enable BitLocker protection on Windows To Go drives before distributing them to users as part of your provisioning process or you can allow your end-users to apply BitLocker protection to them after they have taken possession of the drive.
segment.target: You can choose to enable BitLocker protection on Windows To Go drives before distributing them to users as part of your provisioning process or you can allow your end-users to apply BitLocker protection to them after they have taken possession of the drive.

segment.source: A step-by-step procedure is provided for both scenarios.
segment.target: A step-by-step procedure is provided for both scenarios.

segment.source: Enabling BitLocker during provisioning ensures that your operating system image is always protected by BitLocker.
segment.target: Enabling BitLocker during provisioning ensures that your operating system image is always protected by BitLocker.

segment.source: When enabling BitLocker during the provisioning process you can significantly reduce the time required for encrypting the drive by enabling BitLocker after configuring the disk and just prior to applying the image.
segment.target: When enabling BitLocker during the provisioning process you can significantly reduce the time required for encrypting the drive by enabling BitLocker after configuring the disk and just prior to applying the image.

segment.source: If you use this method, you will need to give users their BitLocker password when you give then their Windows To Go workspace.
segment.target: If you use this method, you will need to give users their BitLocker password when you give then their Windows To Go workspace.

segment.source: Also, you should instruct your users to boot their workspace and change their BitLocker password as soon as possible (this can be done with standard user privileges).
segment.target: Also, you should instruct your users to boot their workspace and change their BitLocker password as soon as possible (this can be done with standard user privileges).

segment.source: Enabling BitLocker after distribution requires that your users turn on BitLocker.
segment.target: Enabling BitLocker after distribution requires that your users turn on BitLocker.

segment.source: This means that your Windows To Go workspaces are unprotected until the user enables BitLocker.
segment.target: This means that your Windows To Go workspaces are unprotected until the user enables BitLocker.

segment.source: Administrative rights on the Windows To Go workspace are required to enable BitLocker.
segment.target: Administrative rights on the Windows To Go workspace are required to enable BitLocker.

segment.source: For more information about BitLocker see the BitLocker Overview.
segment.target: For more information about BitLocker see the BitLocker Overview.

segment.source: BitLocker recovery keys
segment.target: BitLocker recovery keys

segment.source: BitLocker recovery keys are the keys that can be used to unlock a BitLocker protected drive if the standard unlock method fails.
segment.target: BitLocker recovery keys are the keys that can be used to unlock a BitLocker protected drive if the standard unlock method fails.

segment.source: It is recommended that your BitLocker recovery keys be backed up to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).
segment.target: It is recommended that your BitLocker recovery keys be backed up to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).

segment.source: If you do not want to use AD DS to store recovery keys you can save recovery keys to a file or print them.
segment.target: If you do not want to use AD DS to store recovery keys you can save recovery keys to a file or print them.

segment.source: How BitLocker recovery keys are managed differs depending on when BitLocker is enabled.
segment.target: How BitLocker recovery keys are managed differs depending on when BitLocker is enabled.

segment.source: If BitLocker protection is enabled during provisioning, the BitLocker recovery keys will be stored under the computer account of the computer used for provisioning the drives.
segment.target: If BitLocker protection is enabled during provisioning, the BitLocker recovery keys will be stored under the computer account of the computer used for provisioning the drives.

segment.source: If backing up recovery keys to AD DS is not used, the recovery keys will need to be printed or saved to a file for each drive.
segment.target: If backing up recovery keys to AD DS is not used, the recovery keys will need to be printed or saved to a file for each drive.

segment.source: The IT administrator must track which keys were assigned to which Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: The IT administrator must track which keys were assigned to which Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: If BitLocker is enabled after distribution, the recovery key will be backed up to AD DS under the computer account of the workspace.
segment.target: If BitLocker is enabled after distribution, the recovery key will be backed up to AD DS under the computer account of the workspace.

segment.source: If backing up recovery keys to AD DS is not used, they can be printed or saved to a file by the user.
segment.target: If backing up recovery keys to AD DS is not used, they can be printed or saved to a file by the user.

segment.source: If the IT administrator wants a central record of recovery keys, a process by which the user provides the key to the IT department must be put in place.
segment.target: If the IT administrator wants a central record of recovery keys, a process by which the user provides the key to the IT department must be put in place.

segment.source: To enable BitLocker during provisioning
segment.target: To enable BitLocker during provisioning

segment.source: Start the host computer that is running Windows 8.
segment.target: Start the host computer that is running Windows 8.

segment.source: Insert your Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: Insert your Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: Launch an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt by right-clicking the Windows PowerShell shortcut in the taskbar, and then clicking Run as Administrator.
segment.target: Launch an elevated Windows PowerShell prompt by right-clicking the Windows PowerShell shortcut in the taskbar, and then clicking Run as Administrator.

segment.source: Provision the Windows To Go drive using the following cmdlets:
segment.target: Provision the Windows To Go drive using the following cmdlets:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you used the manual method for creating a workspace you should have already provisioned the Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: If you used the manual method for creating a workspace you should have already provisioned the Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: If so, you can continue on to the next step.
segment.target: If so, you can continue on to the next step.

segment.source: Next you need to apply the operating system image that you want to use with Windows To Go to the operating system partition you just created on the disk (this may take 30 minutes or longer, depending on the size of the image and the speed of your USB connection).
segment.target: Next you need to apply the operating system image that you want to use with Windows To Go to the operating system partition you just created on the disk (this may take 30 minutes or longer, depending on the size of the image and the speed of your USB connection).

segment.source: The following command shows how this can be accomplished using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management command-line tool (DISM):
segment.target: The following command shows how this can be accomplished using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management command-line tool (DISM):

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: The index number must be set correctly to a valid Enterprise image in the .WIM file.
segment.target: The index number must be set correctly to a valid Enterprise image in the .WIM file.

segment.source: In the same PowerShell session use the following cmdlet to add a recovery key to the drive:
segment.target: In the same PowerShell session use the following cmdlet to add a recovery key to the drive:

segment.source: Next, use the following cmdlets to save the recovery key to a file:
segment.target: Next, use the following cmdlets to save the recovery key to a file:

segment.source: Then, use the following cmdlets to add the password as a secure string.
segment.target: Then, use the following cmdlets to add the password as a secure string.

segment.source: If you omit the password the cmdlet will prompt you for the password before continuing the operation:
segment.target: If you omit the password the cmdlet will prompt you for the password before continuing the operation:

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: To have BitLocker only encrypt used space on the disk append the parameter to the cmdlet.
segment.target: To have BitLocker only encrypt used space on the disk append the parameter to the cmdlet.

segment.source: As data is added to the drive BitLocker will encrypt additional space.
segment.target: As data is added to the drive BitLocker will encrypt additional space.

segment.source: Using this parameter will speed up the preparation process as a smaller percentage of the disk will require encryption.
segment.target: Using this parameter will speed up the preparation process as a smaller percentage of the disk will require encryption.

segment.source: If you are in a time critical situation where you cannot wait for encryption to complete you can also safely remove the Windows To Go drive during the encryption process.
segment.target: If you are in a time critical situation where you cannot wait for encryption to complete you can also safely remove the Windows To Go drive during the encryption process.

segment.source: The next time the drive is inserted in a computer it will request the BitLocker password.
segment.target: The next time the drive is inserted in a computer it will request the BitLocker password.

segment.source: Once the password is supplied, the encryption process will continue.
segment.target: Once the password is supplied, the encryption process will continue.

segment.source: If you do this, make sure your users know that BitLocker encryption is still in process and that they will be able to use the workspace while the encryption completes in the background.
segment.target: If you do this, make sure your users know that BitLocker encryption is still in process and that they will be able to use the workspace while the encryption completes in the background.

segment.source: Copy the numerical recovery password and save it to a file in a safe location.
segment.target: Copy the numerical recovery password and save it to a file in a safe location.

segment.source: The recovery password will be required if the password is lost or forgotten.
segment.target: The recovery password will be required if the password is lost or forgotten.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: If the Choose how BitLocker-protected removable data drives can be recovered Group Policy setting has been configured to back up recovery information to Active Directory Domain Services, the recovery information for the drive will be stored under the account of the host computer used to apply the recovery key.
segment.target: If the Choose how BitLocker-protected removable data drives can be recovered Group Policy setting has been configured to back up recovery information to Active Directory Domain Services, the recovery information for the drive will be stored under the account of the host computer used to apply the recovery key.

segment.source: If you want to have the recovery information stored under the account of the Windows To Go workspace you can turn BitLocker from within the Windows To Go workspace using the BitLocker Setup Wizard from the BitLocker Control Panel item as described in To enable BitLocker after distribution.
segment.target: If you want to have the recovery information stored under the account of the Windows To Go workspace you can turn BitLocker from within the Windows To Go workspace using the BitLocker Setup Wizard from the BitLocker Control Panel item as described in To enable BitLocker after distribution.

segment.source: Safely remove the Windows To Go drive.
segment.target: Safely remove the Windows To Go drive.

segment.source: The Windows To Go drives are now ready to be distributed to users and are protected by BitLocker.
segment.target: The Windows To Go drives are now ready to be distributed to users and are protected by BitLocker.

segment.source: When you distribute the drives, make sure the users know the following:
segment.target: When you distribute the drives, make sure the users know the following:

segment.source: Initial BitLocker password that they will need to boot the drives.
segment.target: Initial BitLocker password that they will need to boot the drives.

segment.source: Current encryption status.
segment.target: Current encryption status.

segment.source: Instructions to change the BitLocker password after the initial boot.
segment.target: Instructions to change the BitLocker password after the initial boot.

segment.source: Instructions for how to retrieve the recovery password if necessary.
segment.target: Instructions for how to retrieve the recovery password if necessary.

segment.source: This may be a help desk process, an automated password retrieval site, or a person to contact.
segment.target: This may be a help desk process, an automated password retrieval site, or a person to contact.

segment.source: To enable BitLocker after distribution
segment.target: To enable BitLocker after distribution

segment.source: Insert your Windows To Go drive into your host computer (that is currently shut down) and then turn on the computer and boot into your Windows To Go workspace
segment.target: Insert your Windows To Go drive into your host computer (that is currently shut down) and then turn on the computer and boot into your Windows To Go workspace

segment.source: Press Windows logo key+W to open Search Settings, type BitLocker and then select the item for BitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: Press Windows logo key+W to open Search Settings, type BitLocker and then select the item for BitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: The drives on the workspace are displayed, click Turn BitLocker On for the C: drive.
segment.target: The drives on the workspace are displayed, click Turn BitLocker On for the C: drive.

segment.source: The BitLocker Setup Wizard appears.
segment.target: The BitLocker Setup Wizard appears.

segment.source: Complete the steps in the BitLocker Setup Wizard selecting the password protection option.
segment.target: Complete the steps in the BitLocker Setup Wizard selecting the password protection option.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you have not configured the Group Policy setting Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesRequire additional authentication at startup to specify Allow BitLocker without a compatible TPM you will not be able to enable BitLocker from within the Windows To Go workspace.
segment.target: If you have not configured the Group Policy setting Windows ComponentsBitLocker Drive EncryptionOperating System DrivesRequire additional authentication at startup to specify Allow BitLocker without a compatible TPM you will not be able to enable BitLocker from within the Windows To Go workspace.

segment.source: Advanced deployment sample script
segment.target: Advanced deployment sample script

segment.source: The following sample script supports the provisioning of multiple Windows To Go drives and the configuration of offline domain join.
segment.target: The following sample script supports the provisioning of multiple Windows To Go drives and the configuration of offline domain join.

segment.source: The sample script creates an unattend file that streamlines the deployment process so that the initial use of the Windows To Go drive does not prompt the end user for any additional configuration information before starting up.
segment.target: The sample script creates an unattend file that streamlines the deployment process so that the initial use of the Windows To Go drive does not prompt the end user for any additional configuration information before starting up.

segment.source: Prerequisites for running the advanced deployment sample script
segment.target: Prerequisites for running the advanced deployment sample script

segment.source: To run this sample script you must open a Windows PowerShell session as an administrator from a domain-joined computer using an account that has permission to create domain accounts.
segment.target: To run this sample script you must open a Windows PowerShell session as an administrator from a domain-joined computer using an account that has permission to create domain accounts.

segment.source: Using offline domain join is required by this script, since the script does not create a local administrator user account.
segment.target: Using offline domain join is required by this script, since the script does not create a local administrator user account.

segment.source: However, domain membership will automatically put “Domain admins” into the local administrators group.
segment.target: However, domain membership will automatically put “Domain admins” into the local administrators group.

segment.source: Review your domain policies.
segment.target: Review your domain policies.

segment.source: If you are using DirectAccess you will need to modify the djoin.exe command to include the and potentially the parameters.
segment.target: If you are using DirectAccess you will need to modify the djoin.exe command to include the and potentially the parameters.

segment.source: The script needs to use drive letters, so you can only provision half as many drives as you have free drive letters.
segment.target: The script needs to use drive letters, so you can only provision half as many drives as you have free drive letters.

segment.source: To run the advanced deployment sample script
segment.target: To run the advanced deployment sample script

segment.source: Copy entire the code sample titled “Windows To Go multiple drive provisioning sample script” into a PowerShell script (.ps1) file.
segment.target: Copy entire the code sample titled “Windows To Go multiple drive provisioning sample script” into a PowerShell script (.ps1) file.

segment.source: Make the modifications necessary for it to be appropriate to your deployment and save the file.
segment.target: Make the modifications necessary for it to be appropriate to your deployment and save the file.

segment.source: Configure the PowerShell execution policy.
segment.target: Configure the PowerShell execution policy.

segment.source: By default PowerShell’s execution policy is set to Restricted; that means that scripts won’t run until you have explicitly given them permission to.
segment.target: By default PowerShell’s execution policy is set to Restricted; that means that scripts won’t run until you have explicitly given them permission to.

segment.source: To configure PowerShell’s execution policy to allow the script to run, use the following command from an elevated PowerShell prompt:
segment.target: To configure PowerShell’s execution policy to allow the script to run, use the following command from an elevated PowerShell prompt:

segment.source: The RemoteSigned execution policy will prevent unsigned scripts from the internet from running on the computer, but will allow locally created scripts to run.
segment.target: The RemoteSigned execution policy will prevent unsigned scripts from the internet from running on the computer, but will allow locally created scripts to run.

segment.source: For more information on execution policies, see Set-ExecutionPolicy.
segment.target: For more information on execution policies, see Set-ExecutionPolicy.

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: To get online help for any Windows PowerShell cmdlet, whether or not it is installed locally type the following cmdlet, replacing cmdlet-name with the name of the cmdlet you want to see the help for:
segment.target: To get online help for any Windows PowerShell cmdlet, whether or not it is installed locally type the following cmdlet, replacing cmdlet-name with the name of the cmdlet you want to see the help for:

segment.source: This command causes Windows PowerShell to open the online version of the help topic in your default Internet browser.
segment.target: This command causes Windows PowerShell to open the online version of the help topic in your default Internet browser.

segment.source: Windows To Go multiple drive provisioning sample script
segment.target: Windows To Go multiple drive provisioning sample script

segment.source: Considerations when using different USB keyboard layouts with Windows To Go
segment.target: Considerations when using different USB keyboard layouts with Windows To Go

segment.source: Before provisioning your Windows To Go drive you need to consider if your workspace will boot on a computer with a non-English USB keyboard attached.
segment.target: Before provisioning your Windows To Go drive you need to consider if your workspace will boot on a computer with a non-English USB keyboard attached.

segment.source: As described in KB article 927824 there is a known issue where the plug and play ID causes the keyboard to be incorrectly identified as an English 101 key keyboard.
segment.target: As described in KB article 927824 there is a known issue where the plug and play ID causes the keyboard to be incorrectly identified as an English 101 key keyboard.

segment.source: To avoid this problem, you can modify the provisioning script to set the override keyboard parameters.
segment.target: To avoid this problem, you can modify the provisioning script to set the override keyboard parameters.

segment.source: In the PowerShell provisioning script, after the image has been applied, you can add the following commands that will correctly set the keyboard settings.
segment.target: In the PowerShell provisioning script, after the image has been applied, you can add the following commands that will correctly set the keyboard settings.

segment.source: The following example uses the Japanese keyboard layout:
segment.target: The following example uses the Japanese keyboard layout:
